An Indiana statute requires the county auditor to post notice in the county courthouse of the sale of real property for nonpayment of property taxes and to publish notice once each week for three consecutive weeks.  Notice by certified mail must be given to the property owner
column2: but at the time in question in this case
column3: there was no provision for notice by mail or personal service to mortgagees of the property.  The purchaser at a tax sale acquires a certificate of sale that constitutes a lien against the property for the amount paid and is superior to all prior liens.  The tax sale is followed by a 2-year period during which the owner or mortgagee may redeem the property.  If no one redeems the property during this period
column4: the tax sale purchaser may apply for a deed to the property
column5: but before the deed is executed
column6: the county auditor must notify the former owner that he is entitled to redeem the property.  If the property is not redeemed within 30 days
column7: the county auditor may then execute a deed to the purchaser who then acquires an estate in fee simple
column8: free and clear of all liens
column9: and may bring an action to quiet title.  Property on which appellant held a mortgage was sold to appellee for nonpayment of taxes.  Appellant was not notified of the pending sale and did not learn of the sale until more than two years later
column10: by which time the redemption period had run and the mortgagor still owed appellant money on the mortgage.  Appellee then filed suit in state court seeking to quiet title to the property.  The court upheld the tax sale statute against appellant's contention that it had not received constitutionally adequate notice of the pending tax sale and of its opportunity to redeem the property after the sale. The Indiana Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The manner of notice provided to appellant did not meet the requirements of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  Pp.  462 U. S. 795-800.
(a) Prior to an action that will affect an interest in life
column2: liberty
column3: or property protected by the Due Process Clause
column4: a State must provide

column2: under all the circumstances
column3: to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to present their objections.""

column1: Mullane v. Central Hanover Bank & Trust Co.
column3: 339 U. S. 314.  Notice by publication is not reasonably calculated to inform interested parties who can be notified by more effective means such as personal service or mailed notice.  Pp.  462 U. S. 795-797.

column1: (b) Since a mortgagee clearly has a legally protected property interest
column2: he is entitled to notice reasonably calculated to apprise him of a pending tax sale.  Constructive notice to a mortgagee who is identified in the public record does not satisfy the due process requirement of Mullane.  Neither notice by publication and posting nor mailed notice to the property owner are means ""such as one desirous of actually informing the [mortgagee] might reasonably adopt to accomplish it.""  Mullane
column3: supra
column4: at  339 U. S. 315.  Personal service or notice by mail is required even though sophisticated creditors have means at their disposal to discover whether property taxes have not been paid and whether tax sale proceedings are therefore likely to be initiated.  Pp.  462 U. S. 798-800.

column2: reversed and remanded.

column1: |462 u.s. 810|"National Association of Greeting Card Publishers v.
Section 3622(b) of the Postal Reorganization Act (Act) provides that the Postal Rate Commission shall recommend rates for the classes of mail in accordance with nine factors
column2: the third of which ( 3622(b)(3)) is

column1: the requirement that each class of mail or type of mail service bear the direct and indirect postal costs attributable to that class or type plus that portion of all other costs of the Postal Service reasonably assignable to such class or type.""
In reviewing the ratemaking proceedings involved here
column2: the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit -- contrary to earlier decisions of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in reviewing prior ratemaking proceedings -- held that the Act does not require the maximum possible use of cost-of-service principles
column3: including allocation of costs on unverified inferences of causation
column4: but permits use of other approaches
column5: including the Rate Commission's original two-tier approach under which the rate floor for each class of mail was established by first determining the portion of the Postal Service's total costs verifiably caused by (""attributable to"") that class of mail
column6: and then ""reasonably assigning"" remaining costs to the various classes of mail on the basis of the other noncost
column7: discretionary factors set forth in  3622(b).

column1: 1. Although the Act divides ratemaking responsibility between the Rate Commission and the Postal Service
column2: the legislative history and the Act's structure demonstrate that ratemaking authority was vested primarily in the Rate Commission.  Thus
column3: its interpretation of  3622(b) is due deference.  Pp.  462 U. S. 820-821.

column1: 2. In enacting the Act to divest itself of its previous control over setting postal rates
column2: Congress was concerned about the influence of lobbyists and resulting discrimination in rates among classes of postal service
column3: but it did not intend to require maximum use of cost-of-service principles or to eliminate the ratesetter's discretion as to the methods for assigning

column1: costs; it simply removed the ratesetting function from the political arena.  The legislative history does not suggest that Congress viewed the exercise of discretion as an evil in itself.  Pp.  462 U. S. 821-823.

3. The Rate Commission's two-tier approach is a reasonable construction of  3622(b)(3).  The two-tier approach -- one tier based on causation and the second tier based on other factors -- is consistent with the statutory language
column2: and is supported by the legislative history.  Pp.  462 U. S. 823-825.

column1: 4. The statute requires attribution of any costs for which the source can be identified
column2: but leaves it to the Rate Commission
column3: in the first instance
column4: to decide which methods provide reasonable assurance that costs are the result of providing one class of service.  Pp.  462 U. S. 825-833.

column1: (a) The Act does not dictate a specific method for identifying causal relationships between costs and classes of mail
column2: but envisions consideration of all appropriate costing approaches.  Pp.  462 U. S. 825-826.

column1: (b) The Rate Commission acted consistently with the statutory mandate and Congress' policy objectives in refusing to use accounting principles lacking an established causal basis.  On its face
column2: 3622(b)(3) does not deny to the expert ratesetting agency the authority to decide which methods sufficiently identify the requisite causal connection between particular services and particular costs.  The legislative history supports the Rate Commission's view that
column3: when causal analysis is limited by insufficient data
column4: the statute envisions that the Rate Commission will press for better data
column5: rather than construct an ""attribution"" based on unsupported inferences of causation.  Pp.  462 U. S. 826-829.

column1: (c) Because the Rate Commission has decided that methods involving attribution of long-term and short-term variable costs reliably indicate causal connections between classes and postal rates
column2: the Act requires that they be employed.  But the Act's language and legislative history support the Rate Commission's position that Congress did not intend to bar the use of any reliable method of attributing costs.  Pp.  462 U. S. 829-832.

column1: (d) A statement in the legislative history indicating that the rate floor for each class of mail should consist of short-term variable costs does not demonstrate that the Rate Commission's inclusion of long-term variable costs
column2: and consideration of other methods of identifying causation
column3: are inconsistent with the statutory mandate or frustrate Congress' policy.  The statute's plain language and prior legislative history indicate that Congress' broad policy was to mandate a rate floor consisting of all costs that could be identified
column4: in the Rate Commission's view
column5: as causally linked to a class of postal service.  Pp.  462 U. S. 832-833.

column2: affirmed and remanded.
J.
column3: delivered the opinion for a unanimous Court.

column1: The Wyoming Legislature consists of a Senate and a House of Representatives.  The State Constitution provides that each of the State's 23 counties shall constitute a senatorial and representative district and shall have at least one senator and one representative
column2: and requires the senators and representatives to be apportioned among the counties ""as nearly as may be according to the number of their inhabitants.""  A 1981 Wyoming statute reapportioned the House of Representatives and provided for 64 representatives.  Based on the 1980 census placing Wyoming's population at 469
column4: the ideal apportionment would have been 7
column5: 337 persons per representative.  But the reapportionment resulted in an average deviation from population equality of 16% and a maximum deviation of 89%.  Niobrara County
column6: the State's least populous county
column7: was given one representative
column8: even though its population was only 2
column10: the legislature having provided that a county would have a representative even if the statutory formula rounded the county's population to zero.  The legislature also provided that
column11: if Niobrara County's representation were held unconstitutional
column12: it would be combined with a neighboring county in a single district
column13: so that the House would consist of 63 representatives.  Appellants (members of the League of Women Voters and residents of seven counties in which the population per representative is greater than the state average) filed an action in Federal District Court
column14: alleging that granting Niobrara County a representative diluted the voting privileges of appellants and other voters similarly situated in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment
column15: and seeking declaratory and injunctive relief.  The District Court upheld the constitutionality of the reapportionment statute.

column1: Held:  Wyoming has not violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by permitting Niobrara County to have its own representative.  Pp.  462 U. S. 842-848.

(a) Some deviations from population equality may be necessary to permit the States to pursue other legitimate objectives such as ""maintain[ing] the integrity of various political subdivisions"" and ""provid[ing] for compact districts of contiguous territory.""  Reynolds v. Sims
column3: 377 U. S. 578.  But an apportionment plan with population disparities larger

column1: than 10% creates a prima facie case of discrimination
column2: and therefore must be justified by the State
column3: the ultimate inquiry being whether the plan may reasonably be said to advance a rational state policy and
column4: if so whether the population disparities resulting from the plan exceed constitutional limits.  Pp.  462 U. S. 842-843.

column1: (b) This case presents an unusually strong example of an apportionment plan the population variations of which are entirely the result of the consistent and nondiscriminatory application of a legitimate state policy.  Wyoming
column2: since statehood
column3: has followed a constitutional policy of using counties as representative districts and ensuring that each county has one representative.  Moreover
column4: Wyoming has applied the factor of preserving political subdivisions free from any taint of arbitrariness or discrimination.  Pp.  462 U. S. 843-846.

column1: (c) Wyoming's policy of preserving county boundaries justifies the additional deviations from population equality resulting from the provision of representation for Niobrara County.  Considerable population variations would remain even if Niobrara County's representative were eliminated.  Under the 63-member plan
column2: the average deviation per representative would be 13% and the maximum deviation would be 66%.  These statistics make it clear that the grant of a representative to Niobrara County is not a significant cause of the population deviations in Wyoming.  Moreover
column3: the differences between the two plans are justified on the basis of the above policy of preserving county boundaries.  By enacting the 64-member plan
column4: the State ensured that this policy applies nondiscriminatorily
column5: whereas the effect of the 63-member plan would be to deprive Niobrara County voters of their own representative.  Pp.  462 U. S. 846-848.

column2: affirmed.

column1: In a bifurcated trial in a Georgia state court
column2: a jury found respondent guilty of murder and imposed the death penalty.  At the sentencing phase of the trial
column3: the judge instructed the jury that it was authorized to consider all of the evidence received during the guilt phase of the trial as well as all facts and circumstances presented in mitigation or aggravation during the sentencing proceeding
column4: and that it must find and designate in writing the existence of one or more specified statutory aggravating circumstances in order to impose the death penalty.  The jury stated in writing that it found the statutory aggravating circumstances that respondent had a prior conviction of a capital felony
column5: that he had ""a substantial history of serious assaultive criminal convictions
column6: and that the murder was committed by an escapee.  While respondent's appeal was pending
column7: the Georgia Supreme Court held in another case that one of the aggravating circumstances -- ""substantial history of serious assaultive criminal convictions"" -- was unconstitutionally vague.  In respondent's case
column8: the Georgia Supreme Court held that the two other aggravating circumstances adequately supported the sentence.  After the Federal District Court denied respondent's petition for habeas corpus
column9: the Court of Appeals held that respondent's death penalty was invalid.  In response to this Court's certified question
column12: the Georgia Supreme Court explained the state law premises for its view that the failure of one aggravating circumstance does not invalidate a death sentence that is otherwise adequately supported by other aggravating circumstances.  Under Georgia law
column13: the finding of a statutory aggravating circumstance serves a limited purpose -- it identifies those members of the class of persons convicted of murder who are eligible for the death penalty
column14: without furnishing any further guidance to the jury in the exercise of its discretion in determining whether the death penalty should be imposed.

column1: 1. The limited function served by the jury's finding of a statutory aggravating circumstance does not render Georgia's statutory scheme invalid under the holding in Furman v. Georgia
column2: 408 U. S. 238.  Under Georgia's scheme
column3: the jury is required to find and identify in writing at least one valid statutory aggravating circumstance
column4: an individualized

column1: determination must be made on the basis of the defendant's character and the circumstances of the crime
column2: and the State Supreme Court reviews the record of every death penalty proceeding to determine whether the sentence was arbitrary or disproportionate. column1: The Pecos River Compact was entered into by Texas and New Mexico (and approved by Congress) to govern allocation of the waters of the Pecos River
column2: which rises in New Mexico and flows into Texas.  Article III(a) of the Compact requires that New Mexico

column1: not deplete by man's activities the flow of the Pecos River at the New Mexico-Texas state line below an amount which will give to Texas a quantity of water equivalent to that available to Texas under the 1947 condition.""

The Compact establishes the Pecos River Commission (Commission) -- consisting of one Commissioner from each State and a nonvoting representative of the United States -- and empowers it to make all findings of fact necessary to administer the Compact.  The two voting Commissioners were unable to agree when a dispute arose between the States concerning the methods for determining annual shortfalls of state-line water flow with regard to Texas' right to receive as much water as it would have received under the consumption conditions prevailing in New Mexico in 1947.  Texas filed this action against New Mexico (the United States intervened to protect its claims on the waters of the river)
column2: alleging that New Mexico had breached its obligations under Art. III(a) of the Compact and seeking a decree commanding New Mexico to deliver water in accordance with the Compact.  This Court appointed a Special Master
column3: who ultimately filed the report involved here
column4: and the parties filed various exceptions thereto.

column1: 1. Exceptions of the Government and New Mexico to the Master's recommendation that either the United States Commissioner or some other third party be given a vote on the Commission and be empowered to participate in all Commission deliberations are sustained.  Once congressional consent is given to an interstate compact as required by the Compact Clause
column2: the compact is transformed into a law of the United States
column3: and unless the compact is unconstitutional
column4: no court may order relief inconsistent with its express terms.  Here
column5: the Compact provides that the Government Commissioner shall not have the right to vote
column6: and no other third party is given the right to vote on matters before the Commission.  This Court cannot rewrite the Compact so as to provide for a third
column7: tie-breaking vote.  Moreover
column8: the Court's equitable powers have never been exercised so as to appoint quasi-administrative officials

column1: to control the division of interstate waters on a day-to-day basis.  Pp.  462 U. S. 564-566.
2. New Mexico's exception to the Master's alternative recommendation to continue the suit as presently postured is overruled
column2: and the recommendation is accepted.  There is no merit to New Mexico's contention that this Court may do nothing more than review the Commission's official actions
column3: and that the case should be dismissed if it is found either that there is no Commission action to review or that actions taken by the Commission were not arbitrary or capricious.  This Court's original jurisdiction to resolve controversies between two States extends to a suit by one State to enforce its compact with another State or to declare rights under a compact.  Here
column4: fundamental structural considerations of the Compact militate against New Mexico's theory
column5: since
column6: if all questions under the Compact had to be decided by the Commission in the first instance
column7: New Mexico could indefinitely prevent authoritative Commission action solely by exercising its veto on the Commission.  Nor do the Compact's express terms constitute the Commission as the sole arbiter of disputes over New Mexico's Art. III obligations.  Moreover
column8: if authorized representatives of the compacting States have reached an agreement on action to be taken by the Commission
column9: this Court will not review the Commission's action at the behest of one of the States absent extraordinary cause or a precise mandate from Congress.  Pp.  462 U. S. 566-571.

column1: 3. Texas' exception to the Master's recommendation against approval of Texas' motion to adopt a so-called ""Double Mass Analysis"" method for determining when a shortfall in state-line flows has occurred is overruled.  The Compact provides that
column2: until the Commission adopts a more feasible method
column3: an ""inflow-outflow method"" shall be used to measure state-line shortfalls.  The ""Double Mass Analysis"" is not close enough to what the Compact terms an ""inflow-outflow method
column4: as described in the Report of the Engineering Advisory Committee"" to make it acceptable for use in determining New Mexico's compliance with its Art. III obligations.  While the Compact leaves the Commission free to adopt the ""Double Mass Analysis
column5: this Court may not apply it against New Mexico in the absence of Commission action.  Pp.  462 U. S. 571-574.

column6: the court followed a decision of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court

column1: Respondent Navy enlisted men brought an action for damages and other relief in Federal District Court against petitioner superior officers
column2: alleging that petitioners in making duty assignments and performance evaluations and in imposing penalties had discriminated against respondents because of their race in violation of their constitutional rights.  The District Court dismissed the complaint on the grounds that the actions complained of were nonreviewable military decisions
column3: that petitioners were entitled to immunity
column4: and that respondents had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies.  The Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: Held:  Enlisted military personnel may not maintain a suit to recover damages from a superior officer for alleged constitutional violations.  The special status of the military has required
column2: the Constitution has contemplated
column3: Congress has created
column4: and this Court has long recognized two systems of justice:  one for civilians and one for military personnel.  The need for unhesitating and decisive action by military officers and equally disciplined responses by enlisted personnel would be undermined by a judicially created remedy exposing officers to personal liability at the hands of those they are charged to command.  Moreover
column5: Congress
column6: the constitutionally authorized source of authority over the military system of justice
column7: has not provided a damages remedy for claims by military personnel that constitutional rights have been violated by superior officers. Any action to provide a judicial response by way of such a remedy would be inconsistent with Congress' authority.  Taken together
column8: the unique disciplinary structure of the military establishment and Congress' activity in the field constitute ""special factors"" which dictate that it would be inappropriate to provide enlisted military personnel a Bivens-type remedy against their superior officers.  Pp.  462 U. S. 298-305.

column2: reversed and remanded.
C.J.
column3: delivered the opinion for a unanimous Court.

column1: A Virginia trial court accepted respondent's plea of guilty to a charge of manufacturing a controlled substance.  At the hearing at which respondent pleaded guilty
column2: one of petitioner police officers gave a brief account of the search of respondent's apartment that led to the discovery of material typically used in manufacturing the controlled substance.  Thereafter
column3: respondent brought a damages action under 42 U.S.C.1983 in Federal District Court against petitioners
column4: officers who participated in the search of his apartment
column5: alleging that his Fourth Amendment rights had been violated.  The District Court granted summary judgment for petitioners on the ground that respondent's guilty plea to the criminal charge barred his  1983 claim.  The Court of Appeals reversed in pertinent part and remanded.

column1: 1. The  1983 action is not barred on the asserted ground that
column2: under principles of collateral estoppel generally applied by the Virginia courts
column3: respondent's conviction would bar his subsequent civil challenge to police conduct
column4: and that a federal court must therefore give the state conviction the same effect under 28 U.S.C.  1738
column5: which generally requires federal courts to give preclusive effect to state court judgments if the courts of the State from which the judgments emerged would do so.  Under collateral estoppel rules applied by Virginia courts
column6: unless an issue was actually litigated and determined in the prior judicial proceeding
column7: it will not be treated as final for purposes of the later action.  Furthermore
column8: under Virginia law
column9: collateral estoppel precludes litigation of only those issues necessary to support the judgment entered in the first action.  Thus
column10: the collateral estoppel doctrine would not be invoked in this case by Virginia courts for at least three reasons.  First
column11: the legality of the search of respondent's apartment was not litigated in the criminal proceedings.  Second
column12: the criminal proceedings did not decide against respondent any issue on which he must prevail in order to establish his 1983 claim
column13: the only question determined by the guilty plea being whether respondent unlawfully engaged in the manufacture of a controlled substance.  This question is irrelevant to the legality of the search or to respondent's right to compensation from state officials under

column2: none of the issues in the  1983 action could have been ""necessarily"" determined in the criminal proceeding.  A determination as to whether or not the search of respondent's apartment was legal would have been entirely irrelevant in the context of the guilty plea proceeding.  Pp.  462 U. S. 312-317.

column1: 2. Nor is litigation of respondent's  1983 damages claim barred on the asserted ground that
column2: because he had an opportunity to raise his Fourth Amendment claim in the criminal prosecution
column3: by pleading guilty
column4: he should be deemed to have either admitted the legality of the search or waived any Fourth Amendment claim.  The guilty plea in no way constituted an admission that the search of his apartment was proper under the Fourth Amendment.  It may not be assumed that a guilty plea is based on a defendant's determination that he would be unable to prevail on a motion to suppress evidence
column5: since a decision to plead guilty may have any number of other motivations.  Cf. Tollett v. Henderson
column8: 411 U. S. 268.  Similarly
column9: although a guilty plea results in the defendant's loss of any meaningful opportunity he might otherwise have had in the criminal proceeding to challenge the admissibility of evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment
column10: it does not follow that a guilty plea is a ""waiver"" of antecedent Fourth Amendment claims that may be given effect outside the confines of the criminal proceeding.  And while a Fourth Amendment claim ordinarily may not be raised in a habeas corpus proceeding following a guilty plea
column11: that conclusion does not rest on any notion of waiver
column12: but rests on the fact that the claim is irrelevant to the constitutional validity of the conviction.  Thus
column13: the justifications for denying habeas review of Fourth Amendment claims following a guilty plea are inapplicable to an action under  1983.  Adoption of a rule of preclusion in this case would threaten important interests in preserving federal courts as an available forum for the vindication of constitutional rights.  Pp.  462 U. S. 317-323.

column11: that conclusion does not rest on any notion of waiver
column12: but rests on the fact that the claim is irrelevant to the constitutional validity of the conviction.  Thus
column13: the justifications for denying habeas review of Fourth Amendment claims following a guilty plea are inapplicable to an action under  1983. S. 317-323.

column2: respondent Indian Tribe has established a comprehensive scheme for managing the fish and wildlife resources on its reservation in New Mexico.  Federally approved tribal ordinances regulate in detail the conditions under which both members of the Tribe and nonmembers may hunt and fish.  New Mexico has hunting and fishing regulations that conflict with
column3: and in some instances are more restrictive than
column4: the tribal regulations
column5: and the State has applied its regulations to hunting and fishing by nonmembers on the reservation.  The Tribe filed suit in Federal District Court
column6: seeking to prevent the State from regulating on-reservation hunting and fishing.  The District Court ruled in the Tribe's favor and granted declaratory and injunctive relief.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The application of New Mexico's laws to on-reservation hunting and fishing by nonmembers of the Tribe is preempted by the operation of federal law.  Pp.  462 U. S. 330-344.

column2: would interfere with the comprehensive tribal regulatory scheme
column3: and would threaten Congress' overriding objective of encouraging tribal self-government and economic development.  Pp.  462 U. S. 338-341.

column1: (b) The State has failed to identify any interests that would justify the assertion of concurrent regulatory authority. column2: especially where the loss of such revenues is likely to be insubstantial.  Pp.  462 U. S. 341-343.
affirmed.

column2: Inc. v. Parker
a Negro male
column3: after being discharged by petitioner employer in 1977
column4: filed a discrimination charge with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)
column5: which
column6: on November 9
column8: upon finding no reasonable cause to believe the charge was true
column9: sent respondent a Notice of Right to Sue pursuant to  706(f) of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  Previously
column10: while respondent's charge was still pending before the EEOC
column11: two other Negro males formerly employed by petitioner had filed a class action against petitioner in Federal District Court
column12: alleging employment discrimination and purporting to represent a class of which respondent was a member.  Subsequently
column15: the District Court denied the named plaintiffs' motion for class certification
column16: and the action then proceeded as an individual action.  Within 90 days thereafter
column17: but almost two years after receiving his Notice of Right to Sue
column18: respondent filed an action under Title VII against petitioner in Federal District Court
column19: alleging that his discharge was racially motivated.  The District Court granted summary judgment for petitioner on the ground that respondent had failed to file his action within 90 days of receiving his Notice of Right to Sue as required by  706(f)(1).  The Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: Held:  The filing of the class action tolled the statute of limitations for respondent and other members of the putative class.  Since respondent did not receive his Notice of Right to Sue until after the class action was filed
column2: he retained a full 90 days in which to bring suit after class certification was denied
column3: and hence his suit was timely filed.  Pp.  462 U. S. 349-354.

column1: (a) While American Pipe & Constr. Co. v. Utah
column3: concerned only intervenors in a class action
column4: the holding of that case -- that the filing of a class action tolls the running of the applicable statute of limitations for all asserted members of the class -- is to be read as not being limited to intervenors
column5: but as extending to class members filing separate actions.  Otherwise
column6: class members would be led to file individual actions prior to denial of class certification in order to preserve their rights.  The result would be a needless multiplicity of actions -- precisely the situation that Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 and the tolling rule of American Pipe were designed to avoid.  Pp.  462 U. S. 349-351.

column1: (b) Failure to apply American Pipe to class members filing separate actions would also be inconsistent with this Court's reliance on American
Pipe in Eisen v. Carlisle & Jacquelin
column3: where it was held that Rule 23(c)(2) required individual notice to class members so that each of them could decide whether to ""opt out"" of the class and thereby preserve his right to pursue his own lawsuit.  A class member would be unable to pursue his own lawsuit if the limitations period had expired while the class action was pending.  Pp.  462 U. S. 351-352.

column1: (c) A tolling rule for class actions is not inconsistent with the purposes served by statutes of limitations of putting defendants on notice of adverse claims and of preventing plaintiffs from sleeping on their rights.  These ends are met when a class action is filed.  Class members who do not file suit while the class action is pending cannot be accused of sleeping on their rights.  And a class complaint notifies the defendants not only of the claims against them
column2: but also of the number and generic identities of the potential plaintiffs.  Pp.  462 U. S. 352-353.

column1: (d) Once the commencement of a class action suspends the applicable statute of limitations as to all putative members of the class
column2: it remains suspended until class certification is denied.  Pp.  462 U. S. 353-354.
affirmed.
J.

column2: an aerospace engineer employed at the George C. Marshall Space Flight Center
column3: a facility operated by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)
column4: made a number of public statements to the news media highly critical of the Center.  Subsequently
column5: respondent Director of the Center demoted petitioner for making the public statements on the ground that they were false and misleading.  The Federal Employee Appeals Authority upheld the demotion
column6: but the Civil Service Commission's Appeals Review Board
column7: upon reopening the proceeding at petitioner's request
column8: found that the demotion had violated his First Amendment rights.  NASA accepted the Board's recommendation that petitioner be restored to his former position retroactively and that he receive backpay.  While his administrative appeal from the demotion was pending
column9: petitioner filed an action against respondent in an Alabama state court
column10: seeking to recover damages for violation of his First Amendment rights.  Respondent removed the action to Federal District Court
column11: which granted summary judgment for respondent.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column12: holding that petitioner had no cause of action for damages under the First Amendment for retaliatory demotion in view of the available remedies under the Civil Service Commission regulations.

column1: Held:  Because petitioner's claims arise out of an employment relationship that is governed by comprehensive procedural and substantive provisions giving meaningful remedies against the United States
column2: it would be inappropriate for this Court to supplement that regulatory scheme with a new nonstatutory damages remedy.  Pp.  462 U. S. 374-390.

column1: (a) The federal courts' statutory jurisdiction to decide federal questions confers adequate power to award damages to the victim of a constitutional violation even if Congress has not expressly authorized such a remedy.  When Congress provides an alternative remedy
column2: it may indicate its intent that this power should not be exercised.  In the absence of such a congressional directive
column3: the federal courts must make the kind of remedial determination that is inpropriate for a common law tribunal
column4: paying particular heed
column5: however
column6: to any special factors counseling hesitation before authorizing a new kind of federal litigation.  Pp.  462 U. S. 374-380.

column1: (b) The Government's comprehensive scheme protecting civil servants against arbitrary action by supervisors provides meaningful remedies for

employees who may have been unfairly disciplined for making critical comments about their agencies.  Given the history of the development of civil service remedies and the comprehensive nature of the remedies currently available
column2: the question in this case is not what remedy the court should provide for a wrong that would otherwise go unredressed
column3: but whether an elaborate remedial system that has been constructed step by step
column4: with careful attention to policy considerations
column5: should be augmented by the creation of a new judicial remedy for the constitutional violation at issue.  This Court declines to create such a remedy
column6: because Congress is in a better position to decide whether or not the public interest would be served by creating it.  Pp.  462 U. S. 380-390.

column1: An Alabama statute imposes a severance tax on oil and gas extracted from wells located in the State.  In 1979
column2: a statute (Act 79-434) was enacted which increased the tax
column3: exempted royalty owners from the increase
column4: and prohibited producers from passing on the increase to consumers.  Appellant producers were parties to preexisting contracts that provided for allocation of severance taxes among themselves
column5: the royalty owners
column6: and any nonworking interests.  The contracts also required the purchasers to reimburse appellants for severance taxes paid.  After paying the increase in the severance tax under protest
column7: appellants and other producers filed suit in an Alabama state court
column8: seeking a declaratory judgment that Act 79-434 was unconstitutional and a refund of the taxes paid.  Concluding that both the royalty owner exemption and the pass-through prohibition violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and the Contract Clause
column9: and that the pass-through prohibition was also preempted by the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 (NGPA)
column10: the trial court held Act 79-434 invalid in its entirety and ordered appellee Alabama Commissioner of Revenue to refund the taxes.  The Alabama Supreme Court reversed.

column1: 1. The pass-through prohibition of Act 79-434 was preempted by federal law insofar as it applied to sales of gas in interstate commerce
column2: but not insofar as it applied to sales of gas in intrastate commerce.  Pp.  462 U. S. 180-187.
which was enacted in 1938
column3: was intended to occupy the field of wholesale sales of natural gas in interstate commerce.  Alabama's pass-through prohibition trespassed upon the authority of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) under that Act to regulate the wholesale prices of natural gas sold in interstate commerce
column4: for the prohibition bars gas producers from increasing their prices to pass on a particular expense -- the increase in the severance tax -- to their purchasers.  Whether or not producers should be permitted

column1: to recover this expense from their purchasers is a matter within the sphere of FERC's regulatory authority.  Pp.  462 U. S. 184-186.
(b) Although the NGPA extended federal authority to control natural gas prices to the intrastate market
column2: Congress also provided that this extension did not deprive the States of the power to establish a price ceiling for intrastate sales at a level lower than the federal ceiling.  Since a State may establish a lower price ceiling
column3: it may also impose a severance tax and forbid sellers to pass it through to their customers.  Pp.  462 U. S. 186-187.

column1: 2. The royalty owner exemption of Act 79-434 does not violate the Contract Clause
column2: since it did not nullify any contractual obligation of which appellants were the beneficiaries.  The exemption provides only that the incidence of the severance tax increase shall not fall on royalty owners
column3: and nowhere states that producers may not shift the burden of the increase to royalty owners.  Pp.  462 U. S. 187-189.

column1: 3. Nor does the pass-through prohibition of Act 79-434 violate the Contract Clause.  While the prohibition affected contractual obligations of which appellants were the beneficiaries
column2: it does not constitute a ""Law impairing the Obligations of Contracts"" within the meaning of the Contract Clause.  The prohibition imposed a generally applicable rule of conduct
column3: the main effect of which was to shield consumers from the burden of the tax increase.  Its effect on existing contracts permitting producers to pass the increase through to consumers was only incidental.  Cf. Producers Transportation Co. v. Railroad Comm'n of California

column1: 4. Neither the pass-through prohibition nor the royalty owner exemption of Act 79-434 violates the Equal Protection Clause.  Both measures pass muster under the standard of rationality applied in considering equal protection challenges to statutes regulating economic and commercial matters.  The pass-through prohibition plainly bore a rational relationship to the State's legitimate purpose of protecting consumers from excessive prices.  Similarly
column2: the Alabama Legislature could have reasonably determined that the royalty owner exemption would encourage investment in oil or gas production.  Pp.  462 U. S. 195-196.
affirmed in part
column3: reversed in part
column4: and remanded.

The action was later dismissed with prejudice when the Government declined to comply with a discovery order.  Thereafter
column2: respondent filed a request with the FTC for disclosure of certain documents concerning the investigation of the subsidiary
column3: but the FTC denied the request on the ground that the documents were exempt from disclosure under Exemption 5.  Respondent then brought suit in Federal District Court to compel release of the documents.  The District Court held that the documents were exempt from disclosure under Exemption 5 as
column4: inter alia
column5: attorney work product.  The Court of Appeals held that the documents generated during the action against the subsidiary could not be withheld on the basis of the work product rule unless the FTC could show that ""litigation related to the terminated action exists or potentially exists."" column6: and that a requirement that documents must be disclosed in the absence of the existence or potential existence of related litigation best comported with the fact that the work product privilege is a qualified one.

column2: attorney work product is exempt from mandatory disclosure without regard to the status of the litigation for which it was prepared.  By its own terms
column3: Exemption 5 requires reference to whether discovery would normally be required during litigation with the agency.  Under a literal reading of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(3)
column4: the work product of agency attorneys would not be subject to discovery in subsequent litigation unless there was a showing of need
column5: and thus would fall within the scope of Exemption 5.  But regardless of how Rule 26(b)(3) is construed
column6: the Court of Appeals erred in construing Exemption 5 to protect work product material only if related litigation

column1: exists or potentially exists.  The test under Exemption 5 is whether the documents would be ""routinely"" or ""normally"" disclosed upon a showing of relevance.  The Court of Appeals' determination that its rule concerning related litigation best comported with the qualified nature of the work product rule is irrelevant in the FOIA context.  Whether its immunity from discovery is absolute or qualified
column2: a protected document cannot be said to be subject to ""routine"" disclosure. Such materials are thus not ""routinely"" or ""normally"" available to parties in litigation
column3: and hence are exempt under Exemption 5.  This result
column4: by establishing a discrete category of exempt information
column5: implements the FOIA's purpose to provide ""workable"" rules.  Pp.  462 U. S. 23-28.

When respondent mining company acquired a fee interest in land covered by a patent under the Act

column3: and later determined
column4: after a hearing
column5: that the removal of the gravel constituted a trespass in violation of a Department of the Interior regulation for which respondent was liable in damages to the United States.  The Interior Board of Land Appeals affirmed
column6: holding that gravel is a mineral reserved to the United States in patents issued under the SRHA.  Respondent then filed suit in Federal District Court
column7: which affirmed

column2: it must not only be a mineral within a familiar definition of that term
column3: as is gravel
column4: but must also be the type of mineral that Congress intended to reserve to the United States in lands patented under the Act.  Pp.  462 U. S. 42-46.

column5: the mineral reservation in the Act is properly interpreted to include substances
column6: such as gravel
column7: that are mineral in character
column8: can be removed from the soil

column2: and that there is no reason to suppose were intended to be included in the surface estate.  Pp.  462 U. S. 46-56.

column1: The Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax Act of 1980 exempts from the tax imposed by the Act domestic crude oil defined as oil produced from wells located north of the Arctic Circle or on the northerly side of the divide of the Alaska-Aleutian Range and at least 75 miles from the nearest point on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline system.
Held. This exemption does not violate the Uniformity Clause's requirement that taxes be ""uniform throughout the United States.""  Pp.  462 U. S. 80-86.
(a) The Uniformity Clause does not require Congress to devise a tax that falls equally or proportionately on each State
column2: nor does the Clause prevent Congress from defining the subject of a tax by drawing distinctions between similar classes.  Pp.  462 U. S. 80-82.

column1: (b) Identifying ""exempt Alaskan oil"" in terms of its geographic boundaries does not render the exemption invalid.  Neither the language of the Uniformity Clause nor this Court's decisions prohibit all geographically defined classifications.  That Clause gives Congress wide latitude in deciding what to tax
column2: and does not prohibit it from considering geographically isolated problems.  Here
column3: Congress cannot be faulted for determining
column4: based on neutral factors
column5: that ""exempt Alaskan oil"" required separate favorable treatment.  Such determination reflects Congress' considered judgment that unique climatic and geographic conditions required that oil produced from the defined region be exempted from the windfall profit tax
column6: which was devised to tax ""windfalls"" that some oil producers would receive as the result of the deregulation of domestic oil prices that was part of the Government's program to encourage the exploration for and production of oil.  Pp.  462 U. S. 84-86.

The District Court held that the conciliation agreement should prevail with respect to layoffs of employees in conflict with the seniority provisions of the collective bargaining agreement.  The Court of Appeals reversed and compelled petitioner to arbitrate.  Among the grievances arbitrated were those of two employees who had been laid off pursuant to the conciliation agreement and in violation of the collective bargaining agreement.  The arbitrator awarded backpay damages against petitioner under the collective bargaining agreement
column3: interpreting that agreement as not requiring him to follow a contrary prior arbitration award involving the same contractual issue
column4: as providing that the District Court's order did not extinguish petitioner's liability for its breach
column5: and as not providing a good faith defense to claims of violation of its seniority provisions.  Petitioner then brought an action to overturn the award
column6: and the District Court entered summary judgment for petitioner
column7: finding that public policy prevented enforcement of the collective bargaining agreement during the period prior to the Court of Appeals' reversal in the prior action.  The Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: Held:  The award in question is properly to be enforced.  Pp.  461 U. S. 764-772.

column2: here
column3: regardless of what this Court's view might be of the correctness of the arbitrator's contractual interpretation
column4: petitioner and respondent bargained for that interpretation
column5: and a federal court may not second-guess it.  The arbitrator's analysis of the merits of the grievance is entitled to the same deference.  Pp.  461 U. S. 764-766.

column1: (b) Enforcement of the collective bargaining agreement as interpreted by the arbitrator will not compromise the public policy requiring obedience to a court order.  Even assuming that the District Court's order that the conciliation agreement should prevail was a mandatory injunction
column2: nothing in the collective bargaining agreement as interpreted by the arbitrator required petitioner to violate that order.  The arbitrator's award neither mandated layoffs nor required that layoffs be conducted according to the collective bargaining agreement
column3: but simply held retrospectively that the employees were entitled to damages for the prior breach of the seniority provisions.  Petitioner was cornered by its own actions

column4: not to mention petitioner

column1: Respondent States received funds as part of the federal grant-in-aid prog1am under Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA) a program designed to improve the educational opportunities available to disadvantaged children.  Subsequently
column2: federal auditors determined that each State had misapplied the funds.  The Education Appeal Board (Board)
column3: while modifying the auditors' findings
column4: assessed deficiencies against both States.  The Secretary of Education (Secretary) declined to review the orders establishing the deficiencies
column5: and
column6: after a period for comment
column7: the orders became final.  Both States filed petitions for review in the Court of Appeals
column8: which consolidated the cases and held that the Department of Education did not have the authority to issue the orders.

column1: 1. The Court of Appeals had jurisdiction of the cases under both  195 of ESEA -- which permits judicial review in the courts of appeals of the Secretary's final action with respect to audits -- and  455 of the General Education Provisions Act (GEPA) -- which permits such review of actions of the Board.  In the absence of an appealable collateral order
column2: federal courts may exercise jurisdiction only over a final order of the Department of Education.  Here
column3: the fact that the Board's order merely established the amount of the deficiencies
column4: leaving for further ""discussion"" the method of repayment
column5: did not render the orders less than ""final.""  The agency's determination of the deficiencies represented a definitive statement of its position
column6: determining the rights and obligations of the parties.  Pp.  461 U. S. 777-780.

column1: 2. The provisions of  207(a)(1) of ESEA and  115 of GEPA -- which required payments of federal grants to States under ESEA to take into account or make adjustments for any overpayments or underpayments in previous grants -- in effect during the periods in which the audits in these cases were conducted gave the Government the right to recover misused funds granted to a State under Title I of ESEA.  Pp.  461 U. S. 780-790.
(a) The plain language of the statutes recognized this right
column2: and the legislative histoly suppolts this reading.  Pp.  461 U. S. 782-787.

column1: (b) Even if  415 were interpreted to cover payments made ""accidently
column2: it covers misused payments.  Grants of misused funds result from the ""accident"" of the Secretary's reliance on assurances by the State that it will use the funds in a program that complies with Title I
column3: when in fact the recipient misuses the funds.  P.  461 U. S. 787.

column1: (c) To construe  207(a)(1) and 415 to provide for liability does not leave meaningless  185 of the Education Amendments of 1978
column2: which was enacted after the audits here occurred and makes explicit the Secretary's authority to recover funds misspent by the recipient State.  On the contrary
column3: 185 plays an important role in specifying the procedures to be followed in determining the amount of the deficiency and in collecting it.  Pp.  461 U. S. 788-790.

column1: 3. Imposition of liability fo misused funds does not intrfere with state sovereignty in violation of the Tenth Amendment.  Requiring States to honor the obligations voluntarily assumed as a condition of federal funding before recognizing their ownership of the funds does not intrude on their sovereignty.  If the conditions for receiving the funds are valid
column2: the State has no sovereign right to retain the funds without complying with those conditions.  Pp.  461 U. S. 790-791.

column1: 4. The initial determination of the existence and amount of the liability for funds misused by a State is to be made administratively by the Department of Education.  And the State may seek judicial review of such determination in the courts of appeals as to whether the Secretary's findings are supported by substantial evidence and reflect application of the proper legal standards.  Pp.  461 U. S. 791-792.

column1: Petitioner pleaded guilty in a Georgia trial court to burglary and theft by receiving stolen property
column2: but the court
column3: pursuant to the Georgia First Offender's Act
column4: did not enter a judgment of guilt
column5: and sentenced petitioner to probation on the condition that he pay a $500 fine and $250 in restitution
column6: with $100 payable that day
column7: $100 the next day
column8: and the $550 balance within four months.  Petitioner borrowed money and paid the first $200
column9: but about a month later he was laid off from his job
column11: despite repeated efforts
column12: was unable to find other work.  Shortly before the $550 balance became due
column13: he notified the probation office that his payment was going to be late.  Thereafter
column14: the State filed a petition to revoke petitioner's probation because he had not paid the balance
column19: and sentenced petitioner to prison.  The record of the hearing disclosed that petitioner had been unable to find employment and had no assets or income.  The Georgia Court of Appeals rejected petitioner's claim that imprisoning him for inability to pay the fine and make restitution violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  The Georgia Supreme Court denied review.

column1: Held:  A sentencing court cannot properly revoke a defendant's probation for failure to pay a fine and make restitution
column2: absent evidence and findings that he was somehow responsible for the failure or that alternative forms of punishment were inadequate to meet the State's interest in punishment and deterrence
column3: and hence
column4: here the trial court erred in automatically revoking petitioner's probation and turning the fine into a prison sentence without making such a determination.  Pp.  461 U. S. 664-674.

column1: (a) If a State determines a fine or restitution to be the appropriate and adequate penalty for the crime
column2: it may not thereafter imprison a person solely because he lacked the resources to pay it.  Williams v. Illinois
column3: 399 U. S. 235; Tate v. Short
column4: 401 U. S. 395.  If the probationer has willfully refused to pay the fine or restitution when he has the resources to pay or has failed to make sufficient bona fide efforts to seek employment or borrow money to pay
column5: the State is justified in using imprisonment as a sanction to enforce collection.  But if the probationer has made all reasonable bona fide efforts to pay the fine and yet cannot do so through no fault of his own
column6: it is fundamentally unfair to revoke probation automatically without considering whether adequate alternative methods of punishing

column1: the probationer are available to meet the State's interest in punishment and deterrence.  Pp.  461 U. S. 664-669.

(b) The State may not use as the sole justification for imprisonment the poverty or inability of the probationer to pay the fine and to make restitution if he has demonstrated sufficient bona fide efforts to do so.  Pp.  461 U. S. 669-672.

(c) Only if alternative measure of punishment are not adequate to meet the State's interests in punishment and deterrence may the court imprison a probationer who has made sufficient bona fide efforts to pay the fine.  To do otherwise would deprive the probationer of his conditional freedom simply because
column2: through no fault of his own
column3: he cannot pay.  Such a deprivation would be contrary to the fundamental fairness required by the Fourteenth Amendment.  Pp.  461 U. S. 672-673.
reversed and remanded.

column7: granting federal district courts jurisdiction without regard to the amount in controversy of

column1: any nonjury civil action against a foreign state . . . as to any claim for relief in personam with respect to which the foreign state is not entitled to immunity either under sections 1605-1607 of this title or under any applicable international agreement.""

column2: while holding that the Act permitted actions by foreign plaintiffs

column4: but on the ground that the Act exceeded the scope of Art. III of the Constitution
column5: which provides
column6: in part

column8: the Laws of the United States
column9: and Treaties made . . . under their Authority
column11: or the Citizens thereof
column14: or Subjects.""  The court held that neither the Diversity Clause nor the ""Arising Under"" Clause of Art. III is broad enough to support jurisdiction over actions by foreign plaintiffs against foreign sovereigns.

column2: the Act codifies
column3: as a matter of federal law
column4: the restrictive theory of foreign sovereign immunity under which immunity is confined to suits involving the foreign sovereign's public acts
column5: and does not extend to cases arising out of its strictly commercial acts.  If one of the specified exceptions to sovereign immunity applies

column1: 3. Congress did not exceed the scope of Art. III by granting federal district courts subject matter jurisdiction over certain civil actions by foreign plaintiffs against foreign sovereigns where the rule of decision may be provided by state law. column1: At respondents' trial in Federal District Court on charges of kidnaping
column2: transporting women across state lines for immoral purposes
column3: and conspiracy to commit such offenses
column4: the victims' testimony included recitals concerning multiple incidents of rape and sodomy by respondents.  The defense relied on a theory of consent and -- inconsistently -- on the possibility that the victims' identification of respondents was mistaken.  None of the respondents testified.  During the prosecutor's summation to the jury
column5: defense counsel objected when the prosecutor began to comment on the defense evidence
column6: particularly that respondents never challenged the kidnaping
column7: the interstate transportation of the victims
column8: and the sexual acts.  A motion for a mistrial was denied
column9: and the jury returned a guilty verdict as to each respondent on all counts.  The Court of Appeals reversed the convictions and remanded for retrial
column10: concluding that the summation violated respondents' Fifth Amendment rights under Griffin v. California
column11: 380 U. S. 609.  The court declined to rely on the harmless error doctrine
column12: stating that application of the doctrine ""would impermissibly compromise the clear constitutional violation of the defendants' Fifth Amendment rights.""

column1: 1. The Court of Appeals erred in reversing the convictions apparently on the basis that it had the supervisory power to discipline prosecutors for continuing violations of Griffin
column2: supra
column3: regardless of whether the prosecutor's arguments constituted harmless error.  Pp.  461 U. S. 504-509.

column1: (a) The goals that are implicated by supervisory powers -- implementing a remedy for violation of recognized rights
column2: preserving judicial integrity by ensuring that a conviction rests on appropriate considerations before the jury
column3: and deterring illegal conduct -- are not significant in the context of this case if the errors alleged are harmless.  Reversals of convictions under a court's supervisory power must be approached with some caution and with a view toward balancing the interests involved.  Pp.  461 U. S. 505-507.
held that a Griffin error is not per se error requiring automatic reversal
column4: and that a conviction should be affirmed if the reviewing court concludes that
column5: on the whole record
column6: the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.  It is the reviewing court's duty to consider the trial record as a whole and to ignore

column2: including most constitutional violations.  Here
column3: the Court of Appeals' analysis
column4: in making passing reference to the harmless error doctrine but not applying it
column5: failed to strike the balance between disciplining the prosecutor on the one hand and the interest in the prompt administration of justice and the victims' interests in not being subjected to the burdens of another trial on the other.  Pp.  461 U. S. 507-509.

column2: the error identified by the Court of Appeals was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.  This Court has the authority to review records to evaluate a harmless error claim

column4: absent the prosecutor's allusion to the failure of the defense to proffer evidence to rebut the victims' testimony

column7: the interstate transportation of the victims
column8: and the sexual acts.  A motion for a mistrial was denied

column3: after which time the longshoreman's cause of action is irrevocably assigned to his employer. column4: and filed a form (Form LS-206) with the Labor Department indicating the employer's agreement to make payments to respondent.  Approximately 23 months later
column5: the employer terminated the payment of benefits by filing another form (Form LS-208) with the Department.  Respondent subsequently filed suit in Federal District Court to recover for his injuries
column6: alleging that they had been caused by the vessel charterer's negligence.  The District Court dismissed the claim for lack of jurisdiction.  The Court of Appeals reversed

column8: in the absence of a formal compensation order or award entered by the Secretary of Labor

column2: the term ""compensation order"" refers specifically to an administrative award of compensation.  Here

column4: as required by the Act

column2: employers who desire to seek indemnification from a negligent third party may make voluntary compensation payments and obtain a compensation order upon request if there is no disagreement among the parties.  Moreover
column3: even without a statutory assignment of the longshoreman's claims

column5: an employer who seeks to bring an action against a shipowner
column6: charterer
column7: or other third person has little to gain from contesting his liability to the longshoreman under the Act.  Pp.  461 U. S. 538-539.

column1: |461 u.s. 540|"Regan v. Taxation With Representation of Washington
Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 (Code) grants tax exemption to certain nonprofit organizations ""no substantial part of the activities of which is carrying on propaganda
column2: or otherwise attempting to influence legislation.""  Section 170(c)(2) permits taxpayers who contribute to  501(c)(3) organizations to deduct the amount of their contributions on their federal income tax returns.  Section 501(c)(4) grants tax-exempt status to certain nonprofit organizations
column3: but contributions to these organizations are not deductible.  Taxation With Representation of Washington (TWR) is a nonprofit corporation organized to promote its view of the ""public interest"" in the area of federal taxation; it was formed to take over the operation of two other nonprofit organizations
column4: one of which had tax-exempt status under  501(c)(3) and the other under  501(c)(4).  The Internal Revenue Service denied TWR's application for tax-exempt status under  501(c)(3) because it appeared that a substantial part of TWR's activities would consist of attempting to influence legislation.  TWR then brought suit in Federal District Court against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue
column5: the Secretary of the Treasury
column6: and the United States
column7: claiming that  501(c)(3)'s prohibition against substantial lobbying is unconstitutional under the First Amendment by imposing an ""unconstitutional burden"" on the receipt of tax-deductible contributions
column8: and is also unconstitutional under the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause because the Code permits taxpayers to deduct contributions to veterans' organizations that.qualify for tax exemption under  501(c)(19).  The District Court granted summary judgment for the defendants
column9: but the Court of Appeals reversed
column10: holding that  501(c)(3) does not violate the First Amendment
column11: but does violate the Fifth Amendment.

column1: Section 210 of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 (PURPA) was designed to encourage the development of cogeneration facilities and small power production facilities and to reduce the demand for fossil fuels.  Section 210(a) directs the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to prescribe rules requiring electric utilities to deal with qualifying cogeneration and small power facilities.  With respect to utilities' purchases of electricity from such facilities
column2: 210(b) provides that rates set by FERC ""shall be just and reasonable to the electric consumers of the electric utility and in the public interest
column3: shall not discriminate against qualified cogeneration and small power facilities
column4: and shall not exceed ""the incremental cost to the electric utility of alternative electric energy.""  Following rulemaking proceedings
column5: FERC promulgated a rule requiring utilities to purchase electric energy from a qualifying facility at a rate equal to the utility's ""full avoided cost
column6: i.e.
column7: the cost to the utility which
column8: but for the purchase from the qualifying facility
column9: would be incurred by the utility in generating the electricity itself or purchasing the electricity from another source.  FERC also promulgated a rule requiring utilities to make such physical interconnections with cogenerators and small power producers as are necessary to effect purchases or sales of electricity authorized by PURPA.  Upon review
column10: the Court of Appeals vacated both rules
column11: holding that FERC had not adequately explained its adoption of the full-avoided-cost rule
column12: and that it exceeded its statutory authority in promulgating the interconnection rule
column14: which provides that ""[n]o qualifying small power production facility or qualifying cogeneration facility may be exempted under this subsection from"" specified provisions of the Federal Power Act (FPA) which require FERC to afford an opportunity for a hearing before ordering an interconnection.

column1: 1. FERC did not act arbitrarily or capriciously in promulgating the full-avoided-cost rule
column2: which is the maximum rate permissible under

column1: 210(b).  Such rule plainly satisfies the requirement of  210(b) that the rate not discriminate against qualifying cogeneration and small power production facilities.  FERC also adequately explained why the rate is ""just and reasonable to the electric consumers of the electric utility and in the public interest.""  Both the statutory language and the legislative history confirm that Congress did not intend to impose traditional ratemaking concepts on sales by qualifying facilities to utilities.  And although FERC recognized that the rule would not directly provide any rate savings to consumers
column2: it reasonably deemed it more important at this time that the rule would provide a significant incentive for the development of cogeneration and small power production
column3: and that ratepayers and the Nation as a whole will benefit from the decreased reliance on scarce fossil fuels and the more efficient use of energy.  Pp.  461 U. S. 412-418.

column1: 2. Nor did FERC exceed its authority in promulgating the interconnection rule.  The authority granted by  210(a) to promulgate such rules as are necessary to require utilities to deal with qualifying facilities plainly encompasses the power to promulgate rules requiring utilities to make physical connections with such facilities
column2: and FERC reasonably interpreted  210(e)(3) as forbidding it to exempt qualifying facilities from being the ""target"" of interconnection applications by other facilities under the FPA
column3: but not as forbidding it to grant qualifying facilities the right to obtain interconnections under PURPA without applying for an order under the FPA.  Such interpretation is supported by the purposes of PURPA and the statutory scheme created by both Acts.  Pp.  461 U. S. 418-423.
reversed and remanded.

column2: on behalf of all persons involuntarily confined in the forensic unit of a Missouri state hospital
column3: brought suit in Federal District Court against petitioner hospital officials
column4: challenging the constitutionality of treatment and conditions at the hospital.  The District Court
column5: after a trial
column6: found constitutional violations in five of the six general areas of treatment.  Subsequently
column7: respondents filed a request for attorney's fees under the Civil Rights Attorney's Fees Awards Act of 1976
column11: ""the court
column15: a reasonable attorney's fee as part of the costs.""  After determining that respondents were prevailing parties under  1988 even though they had not succeeded on every claim
column16: the District Court refused to eliminate from the attorney's fees award the hours spent by respondents' attorneys on the unsuccessful claims
column17: finding that the significant extent of the relief clearly justified the award of a reasonable attorney's fee.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  The District Court did not properly consider the relationship between the extent of success and the amount of the attorney's fee award.  The extent of a plaintiff's success is a crucial factor in determining the proper amount of an attorney's fee award under  1988.  Where the plaintiff failed to prevail on a claim unrelated to the successful claims
column2: the hours spent on the unsuccessful claim should be excluded in considering the amount of a reasonable fee.  Where a lawsuit consists of related claims
column3: a plaintiff who has won substantial relief should not have his attorney's fee reduced simply because the district court did not adopt each contention raised.  But where the plaintiff achieved only limited success
column4: the court should award only that amount of fees that is reasonable in relation to the results obtained.  Pp.  461 U. S. 429-440.

column1: To be entitled to disability benefits under the Social Security Act
column2: a person must not only be unable to perform his former work but must also be unable
column3: considering his age
column4: education
column5: and work experience
column6: to perform any other kind of gainful work that exists in the national economy.  Prior to 1978
column7: in cases where a claimant was found unable to pursue his former occupation
column8: but his disability was not so severe as to prevent his pursuing any gainful work
column9: the Secretary of Health and Human Services (Secretary) relied on vocational experts to determine whether jobs existed in the national economy that the claimant could perform.  In 1978
column10: to improve the uniformity and efficiency of such determinations
column11: the Secretary promulgated medical-vocational guidelines setting forth rules to establish whether such jobs exist.  If a claimant's qualifications correspond to the job requirements identified by a rule
column12: the guidelines direct a conclusion as to whether work exists that the claimant can perform.  If such work exists
column13: the claimant is not considered disabled.  After respondent's application for disability benefits was denied
column14: she requested a hearing before an Administrative Law Judge
column17: found that jobs existed that a person of respondent's qualifications could perform
column18: and accordingly concluded that she was not disabled.  Both the Social Security Appeals Council and the District Court upheld this determination. But the Court of Appeals reversed
column19: holding that the guidelines did not provide adequate evidence of specific alternative jobs that respondent could perform
column21: in the absence of such evidence
column22: respondent was deprived of any chance to present evidence that she could not perform the types of jobs identified by the guidelines
column23: and that therefore the determination that she was not disabled was not supported by substantial evidence.

column1: Held:  The Secretary's use of the medical-vocational guidelines to determine a claimant's right to disability benefits does not conflict with the Social Security Act
column2: nor are the guidelines arbitrary or capricious.  Pp.  461 U. S. 465-470.

column1: (a) While the statutory scheme contemplates that disability hearings will be individualized determinations based on evidence
column2: this does not bar the Secretary from relying on rulemaking to resolve certain classes of issues.  The determination as to whether jobs exist that a person having

column1: the claimant's qualifications could perform requires the Secretary to determine a factual issue that is not unique to each claimant
column2: and may be resolved as fairly through rulemaking as by introducing testimony of vocational experts at each disability hearing.  To require the Secretary to relitigate the existence of jobs in the national economy at each hearing would hinder an already overburdened agency.  Pp.  461 U. S. 465-468.

column1: (b) The principle of administrative law that
column2: when an agency takes official or administrative notice of facts
column3: a litigant must be given an adequate opportunity to respond is inapplicable where
column4: as in this case
column5: the agency has promulgated valid regulations.  When the accuracy of such facts has been tested fairly during rulemaking
column6: the rulemaking proceeding itself provides sufficient procedural protection.  Pp.  461 U. S. 468-470.

column1: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) summoned respondent Rylander (respondent) to appear before an IRS agent and to produce for examination
column2: and testify with respect to
column3: records of two corporations of which respondent was president.  When respondent failed to comply with the summons
column4: the District Court enforced it and ordered him to produce the corporate records.  Subsequently
column5: after a hearing
column6: the District Court held respondent in civil contempt for failure to comply with the court's enforcement order
column7: finding that he had failed to introduce any evidence in support of his claim that he did not possess the records.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column8: holding that respondent's out-of-court declaration that he did not possess the documents
column9: together with his invocation of the privilege against self-incrimination under the Fifth Amendment
column10: required the Government to shoulder the burden of producing evidence that respondent was able to produce the records in question
column11: and that
column12: notwithstanding the issuance of the enforcement order
column13: respondent was free to relitigate the question of his possession or control of the records in the contempt proceeding.

column1: Held:  The Court of Appeals was incorrect both in its view of the relationship between the enforcement proceeding and the contempt proceeding and in its view of the effect of respondent's invocation of his Fifth Amendment privilege on the burden of production at the contempt hearing.  Pp.  460 U. S. 756-762.
(a) Because a proceeding to enforce an IRS summons is an adversary proceeding in which the defendant may contest the summons on any appropriate ground
column2: and because lack of possession or control of records is such a ground
column3: the issue may not be raised for the first time in a contempt proceeding.  In the latter proceeding
column4: the defendant may assert a present inability to comply with the enforcement order
column5: but in raising this defense
column6: he has the burden of production.  Thus
column7: while respondent in the contempt hearing could not attack the enforcement order on the ground that he lacked possession or control of the records at the time the order was issued
column8: he could defend the contempt charge on the ground that he was then unable to comply because he lacked possession or control.  Pp.  460 U. S. 756-757.

column1: (b) While assertion of the Fifth Amendment privilege may be a valid ground upon which a witness such as respondent declines to answer questions
column2: it is not a substitute for evidence that would assist in meeting a burden of production.  Curcio v. United States
column4: distinguished.  The Court of Appeals' view would convert the privilege from the shield against compulsory self-incrimination that it was intended to be into a sword whereby a claimant asserting the privilege would be freed from adducing proof in support of a burden that would otherwise have been his.  Pp.  460 U. S. 757-761.
